Background and Purpose Background Child abuse and neglect, youth violence, teen dating violence, and sexual violence are major public health issues impacting children and youth. The mission of the National Center for Injury Prevention and Control (NCIPC) is to prevent injuries and violence through surveillance, research and evaluation, and prevention action. CDC's NCIPC uses the same scientific methods Page 9 of 61 to prevent injuries and violence that have been used to prevent disease: carefully describing the problem through surveillance, studying factors that increase or decrease risk for violence or injury, designing and evaluating prevention strategies that address these risk and protective factors, and taking steps to ensure that proven strategies are implemented in communities nationwide. For 30 years, CDC's NCIPC has studied injuries and violence and investigated the best ways to prevent them. We translate science into real-world solutions to prevent violence and injuries before they happen. Research is fundamental to our success in violence prevention, because good research is essential in making sound, smart investments in prevention action. Research provides the knowledge that we need to understand what is possible, what is not, and the best way to progress in our prevention efforts. The CDC has developed a suite of technical packages to help states and communities leverage the best available evidence to prevent multiple forms of violence (see: https://www.cdc.gov/violenceprevention/communicationresources/pub/technical- packages.html). CDC has also developed a prevention resource to prevent adverse childhood experiences (ACEs) that draws upon these technical packages (see: https://www.cdc.gov/violenceprevention/pdf/preventingACES.pdf). Strong, innovative, and relevant research is fueled by a diverse field of qualified researchers. NCIPC values supporting new investigators to build capacity to grow the field of violence prevention and become experienced independent investigators. New investigator awards support career trajectories to prepare new investigators to conduct independent research later as a principal investigator of research grants (R01) and cooperative agreements (U01). The intent of Notice of Funding Opportunity (NOFO) RFA-CE-23-003 is to contribute to the development of new researchers in the field of violence prevention. By providing resources to new investigators, they can develop and conduct research that addresses NCIPC's interpersonal violence prevention research priorities and acquire new skills. The NCIPC Research Priorities serve as a foundation for NCIPC's research funding and briefly describe key gaps in the field of violence prevention that need to be addressed to inform prevention activities (https://www.cdc.gov/injury/researchpriorities/index.html). This NOFO is specifically focused on addressing the interpersonal forms of violence impacting children or youth from birth through age 17 (i.e., child abuse and neglect, youth violence, teen dating violence, and sexual violence). Applicants may propose research that focuses on a subset of ages between 0 and 17. Applicants may also include participants outside this age range, but the application should describe how the research question and results are relevant to those ages 0-17. Applicants must propose violence prevention research that focuses on at least one of the interpersonal violence prevention research gaps in the NCIPC Research Priorities and examines one or more forms of violence impacting children and youth. Exposure to violence or other adverse childhood experiences can negatively affect health and development across the lifespan. Multiple forms of violence affect children and youth, including child abuse and neglect, youth violence, teen dating violence, and sexual violence. These forms of violence often share risk and protective factors. Despite these linkages, research is often Page 10 of 61 focused on a specific form of violence in ways that limit our understanding of whether prevention strategies have cross-cutting impacts. CDC's Division of Violence Prevention's Strategic Vision includes "addressing factors that cut across multiple forms of violence" as a guiding principle (see https://www.cdc.gov/violenceprevention/publichealthissue/strategicvision.html). Applicants are encouraged to address multiple forms of violence impacting children or youth when possible. Importantly, the majority of children and youth aged 0-17 who were victims of homicide in 2020 died from firearm-related injuries. Thus, applicants are encouraged to examine firearm-related behavior, crime, injuries, and deaths among children and youth or include firearm-related behavior, crime, injuries, and deaths among children and youth as outcomes. Using the public health approach, NCIPC is committed to supporting research to reduce the burden of violence and inequities across groups. The social and structural conditions in which people are born, grow, live, work, and age can be shaped by the distribution of resources, which is influenced in part by policy. These social determinants of health (e.g., concentrated poverty, structural racism, high rates of unemployment and community violence, limited access to high- quality education and /or affordable, high-quality child care) contribute to health inequities, including the differences in health status seen across population groups. Research related to addressing the social or structural conditions that contribute to violence and health inequities across population groups is also encouraged. Relevant Work For 30 years, NCIPC has been the nation's leading public health authority on violence and injury prevention. NCIPC's approach involves three elements: a focus on prevention, a science-driven approach to identify risk and patterns that influence risk and protective factors, and multidisciplinary collaboration to address the problem and keep people safe, healthy, and productive. NCIPC's Division of Violence Prevention has developed and published technical packages to help states and communities take advantage of the best available evidence to prevent violence (https://www.cdc.gov/violenceprevention/pub/technical-packages.html). The strategies and approaches in the technical package represent different levels of the social ecology with efforts intended to impact individual behaviors as well as the relationship, family, school, community, and societal factors that influence risk and protective factors for violence. CDC has also released an ACEs prevention resource that highlights six ACEs prevention strategies drawn from CDC technical packages (https://www.cdc.gov/violenceprevention/pdf/preventingACES.pdf). NCIPC's research priorities (https://www.cdc.gov/injury/researchpriorities/index.html) and the Division of Violence Prevention's Strategic Vision (https://www.cdc.gov/violenceprevention/publichealthissue/strategicvision.html) support the need for prevention strategies that address multiple forms of violence. A key goal of CDC's research is to enhance the effects of violence prevention activities by focusing on the interconnections across the different forms of violence. Cross-cutting violence prevention activities can use resources more effectively and help achieve health equity by focusing on the underlying conditions that contribute to increased risk. Examples of previously-funded research and descriptions of violence prevention initiatives are available on NCIPC's website: https://www.cdc.gov/violenceprevention/publichealthissue/fundedprograms/research- awards.html 2.
